node.title: Phase field fracture (simple and cohesive zone model)
node.bodyText: Can anyone guide where will the easy tutorials be found for learning as a beginner? I have already gone through every phase field theory and examples available on moose platform. I am finding difficulty in writing my own personal input file with imported mesh. Are there any handbook or step by step guidelines available for writing moose code?

https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Mesh/ talks about the mesh system.
Phase field fracture examples can be found in modules/combined/test/tests/phase_field_fracture.
There is an external app called RACCOON that specializes in phase field fracture. AT1, AT2, PFCZM, etc.
DG-like CZM examples are in modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/cohesive_zone_model
You really helped me a lot
Especially the third point
thank you

Hello
You are on the right track with using valgrind to find the bug, but you will want to use a debug version of the code.
So instead of make -j6, use METHOD=dbg make -j6 then use the newly created dbg executable

This is what I got with the debug executable.
valgrind _dbg.txt

hello
is this file in Moose? I can't find ComputeGBMisorientationAngle
 ==227349==    at 0x90F153C: ComputeGBMisorientationAngle::getMisorientationAngles() (ComputeGBMisorientationAngle.C:234)

No. I made that material to calculate the misorientation angle derived from ComputeGBMisorientationType. But the error is still there with this material. But input file runs fine with the example ebsd file.
Following is the valgrind output with ComputeGBMisorientationType.
valgrind_dbg_1.txt

I cannot reproduce this on my machine.
I am using the output_data.txt file and the ComputeGBMisorientationType (since ComputeGBMisorientationAngle is custom) and the error does not occur, even in debug mode.
I printed and we are not accessing out of bounds.
I will add an assert to that code and you can see if debug mode hits the assertion on your machine. This could be a clue
otherwise please print graid_id and grain_num in the loop where it crashes and see if it goes wrong

Hello Guillaume,
Sorry for not updating you on this. I think I figured it out what was the issue here. In the EBSD file (output_data.txt) generated by Dream3d, the grainID was indexed starting from 1 instead of 0. When I changed that, the simulations ran smoothly.
It was a very small change.
Thank you again for help.
Ashish
thanks for reporting back. I made a note of it and we'll catch it properly in the future

node.title: MOOSE build fail on INL HPC
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 I have consulted the Posting Guidelines.
 I have searched the Discussions Forum and MOOSE Framework Troubleshooting and have not found what I was looking for
 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)

Issue or question about MOOSE
I tempted to build MOOSE on INL HPC for one of my projects, and I strictly followed the procedure outlined here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/inl_hpc_install_moose.html
Everything was fine until these commands were executed :
cd ~/cluster_name/projects/moose/test
make -j 6
The generated errors are screen captured here:

Please assist me further with this error. I have tried this via Sawtooth2 shell terminal, and launched it from INL HPC on demand via my employee credentials.
(Optional) code in question / simulation log / errors
No response
Encountering Errors? Please include diagnostic output
No response

This annotation is pretty important, and may be the cause for the failure.

Basically, if you ran make in ~/cluster_name/projects/moose using any other machine other than sawtooth (the one you are using now), the error you are receiving may occur. Which is why we instruct users to separated their projects directory, labeled by way of HPC clusters available:
ssh sawtooth1 (or 2)
cd ~/sawtooth/projects/moose
make

ssh lemhi1 (or 2)
cd ~/lemhi/projects/moose
make

# Bitterroot is broken at the moment, but the idea is the same
ssh bitterroot1 (or 2)
cd ~/bitterroot/projects/moose
make
and etc.
In order to fix this, you will need to clean out your current repository, and build anew (add any untracked files before doing so, or they will be lost. If you have made no changes to MOOSe, you can ignore this comment):
module purge
module load use.moose moose-dev
cd ~/cluster_name/projects/moose
git clean -xfd
git submodule foreach --recursive git clean -xfd
Once cleaned, you should be able to run make:
cd test
make -j 6

I forgot to mention:
It might also be necessary to rebuild PETSc, libMesh, and WASP, for the same reasons above.
I encountered the same issue as you. Did you manage to solve it?

Hi @jakson121,
I posted this question in the context of MOOSE compiled via INL's HPC. IF you compiled MOOSE under a similar context, please let me know and we ma y figure things out.
@jakson121 's originating issue: #28345

@ver2king, were you able to resolve this?
When I build on sawtooth2, using module load use.moose moose-dev, I am not running into an issue.

@milljm , I were able to solve this. Before using module load use.moose moose-dev, ensure to enter the correct cluster via ssh (for example: ssh sawtooth1). Also, ensure to re-build all petsc, libmesh and wasp. I tried on both sawtooth1 and sawtooth2 and have seen no problem.

Issue or question about MOOSE

Hello
Is this a fresh install?
These errors are often seen when leftover compiled objects are present from a previous installation of the code
yes，I am installing MOOSE using the cluster method, but I encountered this issue during compilation. Do you know how to solve it?

Can you provide the results of a diagnostic?
cd ~/projects/moose/scripts
./diagnostics.sh

PETSC_ARCH=test
PETSC_DIR=/home/junjie/software/petsc-3.21.3
REQUESTS_CA_BUNDLE=
SSL_CERT_FILE=
##################################################################################################
Compiler(s) (CC CXX FC F77 F90):
CC              not set
CXX             not set
FC              not set
F77             not set
F90             not set
FAIL: One or more compiler environment variables not set
##################################################################################################
Python Sanity Checks
Verify /usr/bin/env python3 --version (reporting as: Python 3.10.12),
matches versions for: which python3 && which python
WARNING: python does not exist
This does not mean there will be a failure, but some shebangs in some python
files may still be relying on calling: /usr/bin/env python (Python 2.x era)

Python Modules (TestHarness, run-ability)

This feels like you are running in a WSL session. Which is fine, but usually folks install our Conda packages when doing so. It is not a hard requirement of course, one could install everything from scratch. And if you have, what seems to be missing here is setting the necessary compiler environment variables.
I am not sure what to have you set those to, but we can see what happens:
export CC=mpicc CXX=mpicxx FC=mpifort F90=mpif90 F77=mpif77
# and then run diags again, see what it detects:
./diagnostics.sh

node.title: Floating Point Exception in Debug after Update
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello,
I updated MOOSE and Conda today and now I can't use the debug build anymore. I followed these steps from the New Users page to update.
cd ~/projects/moose
git fetch origin
git rebase origin/master

conda activate base
conda env remove -n moose
conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.07.19
conda activate moose

cd ~/projects/YourAppName
make clobberall
make 

The input doesn't matter. Top opt build is working fine. But as soon as I try to debug, this happens:
Time Step 0, time = 0

Time Step 1, time = 0.05, dt = 0.05

What should I do?

Looks like you installed our OpenMPI variant packages, which is a bit under-tested. Can you do the following and see if this solves your issue?
conda deactivate
conda activate base
conda env remove -n moose
conda create -n moose moose-dev=2024.07.19 mpich
conda activate moose
cd ~/projects/YourAppName
make clobberall
make -j 6
We're in the process of updating our instructions right now for this very reason, ref: #28195

Interesting

  [right_pressure_function]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = '-0.001 * t'
  []
[]

# Material: Volume Elements
[Materials]

  [elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    block = 'BaseMesh Box1'
    youngs_modulus = 1e6
    poissons_ratio = 0.25
  []

  [stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
    block = 'BaseMesh Box1'
  []

[]

# Material: Shell Elements
[Materials]
  [shell_elasticity]
    type = ADComputeIsotropicElasticityTensorShell
    block = 'Box1Hull_LowerDElements'
    youngs_modulus = 1e9
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
    through_thickness_order = SECOND
  []
  [shell_strain]
    type = ADComputeIncrementalShellStrain
    block = 'Box1Hull_LowerDElements'
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
    rotations = 'rot_x rot_y'
    thickness = 1.0
    through_thickness_order = SECOND
  []
  [shell_stress]
    type = ADComputeShellStress
    block = 'Box1Hull_LowerDElements'
    through_thickness_order = SECOND
  []
[]


# move elements between subdomains back and forth
[UserObjects]
  [GlobalSubdomainModifier]
    type = TimedSubdomainModifier
    times = '0.2 0.4'
    blocks_from = 'Box1 Box1Hull_LowerDElements'
    blocks_to = 'Box1_inactive Box1Hull_LowerDElements_inactive'
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [.\SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient

  end_time = 1.0
  dtmin = 0.001
  [TimeSteppers]
    [BlockEventTimeStepper]
      type = TimeSequenceStepper
      time_sequence = '0.05 0.1 0.2 0.4 1.0'
    []
  []

  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package'
  petsc_options_value = ' lu       mumps'

  l_tol = 1E-10
  l_max_its = 20

  nl_abs_tol = 1E-10
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
  nl_max_its = 20

[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

node.title: Debugging of Moose Application in VSCode in UbuntuOS
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose Team,
I am a new MOOSE user, currently learning to use the framework. I have a question regarding debugging a MOOSE application in VSCode on Ubuntu OS.
I am using the following launch.json configuration in VSCode:
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "by-gdb",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch(gdb)",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/rhocp-dbg",
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "programArgs": "-i examples/bcc_FeCr/test1p5/bcc_pxtal.i"
        }
    ]
}
I have two queries regarding debugging:


It takes a long time (4-5 minutes) for VSCode to launch the MOOSE application for debugging. Is there any way to speed up this process? My PC specs are decent: a parallel Xeon processor with 20 CPUs and 128GB RAM. I have installed MOOSE manually, compiling libmesh, PETSc, and WASP myself.


By default, the MOOSE application is launched in the VSCode debugger with 4 threads. Is there a way to configure it to launch with only 1 thread? I have tried the option of -n-threads=1 still MOOSE is lauched with 4 threads.


Thank you for considering my queries. I look forward to your response.

Hello

It takes a long time (4-5 minutes) for VSCode to launch the MOOSE application for debugging

How long does it take to:

run an opt application instead of a debugging one from VSCode?
run the debugger outside of vscode ?

For 2, it should be --n-threads=1 not -n-threads=1, so one additional dash.
Does that work?

Hi Giudicelli,
Thank you for your reply. Please find the answers to your queries below:
The opt application and command line debugging in gdb start almost instantaneously.
Apologies for the typo in my previous message. I was using --n-threads=1 as intended. However, the debugger still starts with 4 threads, as shown below:
{

    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "by-gdb",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch(gdb)",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/rhocp-dbg",
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "programArgs": "-i examples/bcc_FeCr/test1p5/bcc_pxtal.i --n-threads=1"
        }
    ]
}

Umm. Can you step in those threads to see what they are doing?
I know one is just the perf graph thread, it does not do much

HI Giudicelli,
Thank you for the hint.
Below are the stack frames for each of the 4 individual MOOSE threads:


Looking at the stack frames, it seems no calculations are being carried out by the threads—they appear to be used solely for timing and monitoring purposes.
This time, I started the VSCode debugger with the following configuration:
        {
            "name": "Attach to C++ process",
            "type": "cppdbg",
            "request": "attach",
            "processId": "${command:pickProcess}",
            "program": "${workspaceFolder}/rhocp-dbg",
            "MIMode": "gdb",
            "setupCommands": [
                {
                    "description": "Enable pretty-printing for gdb",
                    "text": "-enable-pretty-printing",
                    "ignoreFailures": true
                }
            ]
        }
Its relatively faster (1-2 mint). Is there any other way to speed up this lauching process.

I dont know about the two middle threads. The last one might be the perf graph one.
@loganharbour @dschwen  do you know a faster debugger configuration?
I don't. I tried quite a while ago getting some of the debugging extensions working, but ran out of patience.

Hello,
I understand your concerns regarding the debugging process with MOOSE in VSCode on Ubuntu. Let me try to address your queries:


Slow launch time for debugging:

The launch time for a MOOSE application can be influenced by several factors, such as the complexity of the input file, the size of the simulation, and the overall system performance.
Since you have a powerful machine with a Xeon processor and 128GB of RAM, the launch time should be relatively faster. However, there are a few things you can try to potentially improve the startup time:

Ensure that you have the latest version of VSCode and the necessary extensions installed (e.g., C/C++ extension).
Check if you have any other processes or applications running in the background that might be consuming system resources.
Consider profiling your MOOSE application to identify any potential performance bottlenecks.
Consult the MOOSE documentation or the MOOSE community forum for any specific recommendations or troubleshooting steps related to debugging performance.





Configuring the number of threads:

The MOOSE framework is designed to take advantage of multi-threading to improve performance. By default, it will launch the application with the maximum number of available threads on your system.
To configure the number of threads, you can use the --n-threads or -n command-line argument when launching your MOOSE application. For example, to run with a single thread, you can use the following in your launch.json file:
"programArgs": "-i examples/bcc_FeCr/test1p5/bcc_pxtal.i --n-threads=1"


Alternatively, you can set the environment variable OMP_NUM_THREADS to the desired number of threads before launching the MOOSE application. For example:
"env": {
    "OMP_NUM_THREADS": "1"
}


Keep in mind that running with fewer threads may not necessarily improve performance, as it depends on the specific problem and the parallelization capabilities of your MOOSE application.



I hope these suggestions help you address the issues you're facing with debugging your MOOSE application in VSCode. If you continue to experience problems, don't hesitate to reach out to the MOOSE community or the MOOSE development team for further assistance.

Hello
A material property in moose is an array (indexed by quadrature point) of the type of the property. So here, you have an array of std::vector.
And you are trying to cast it into a vector, with this value() function which does not exist for arrays.
So instead, I think you mean to index into the array? Which quadrature point value do you need?

In the header you have acc_slip before num_slip_systems, but in the constructor you have the initialized the other way (num_slip_systems first)

  530 |    std::fill(_acc_slip.begin(), _acc_slip.end(), std::vector<Real>(_num_slip_systems, 0.0));
      |                        ^~~~~

first one is a missing symbol, maybe a comma
_acc_slip[qp] is not a vector.
did you declare it as a single valued material property? (with <double> in the template instantiation)

node.title: Query Regarding Displaced Mesh in the New Moose Syntax System
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose Team,
I’m a new Moose user and currently in the process of learning the platform. I have a question regarding the use of displaced meshes in the newer syntax system—specifically within the Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic system.
In the older syntax, this variable was specified like this:
[Kernels/TensorMechanics]
  use_displaced_mesh = true
[]

However, I couldn't find a corresponding input variable in the new Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic system. How can I specify the use of a displaced mesh in this updated syntax? Is it enabled by default, or is there another method to achieve this?
Thank you for your assistance.

Hello
It should be turned on/off by default based on what models you are using, making the right selection for each option the Physics is giving you.
You should not need to worry about in the Physics.
In the simulation header, do you see the displacements variables being created?
Guillaume

Hi Giudicelli,
Thank you for your reply.
I am performing a crystal plasticity analysis.
Previously, I specified the displaced mesh option using the following settings:
[Kernels]
  [./TensorMechanics]
    strain = FINITE
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
    use_displaced_mesh = true
  [../]
[]

You mentioned that the displaced mesh option will be enabled by default if I select the correct options in the physics section. Could you clarify which options I need to select?
Currently, I am using the following options:
[Physics]
  [SolidMechanics]
    [QuasiStatic]
      [all]
        strain = FINITE
        add_variables = true
        #use_displaced_mesh = true
      []
    []
  []
[]

Additionally, I'm having trouble understanding this part of your message:
In the simulation header, do you see the displacement variables being created?

Are you referring to the log file?

I am referring to the log file
Yes the syntax should be basically the same between the old kernels syntax and the Physics
Thank you Giudicelli for your help.

You should research on the petsc manual this error code

Guillaume

@Emmanuel-324  I don't know how big is your domain and how much strain you are applying, but from my experience that behavior is due to the time step being too large. Try reducing the time step and see if it can avoid the unconverged steps. For the crystal plasticity model, my experience is that aiming for 0.01% strain increase, or less, for each time step will lead to good convergence. It depends on the constitutive model though. As @GiudGiud  says, regular unconverged steps will lead to a very slow simulation overall.
My domain is a 2D 300 by 300 mesh. I am applying a constant displacement. I am hoping to get a strain of at least 0.008. Thanks, I will try your suggestion.
Did you try taking smaller time steps?

When you say smaller timesteps do you mean smaller timestep interval or the total time of the simulation.
Below is what my executioner block looks like
 [Executioner]
   type = Transient
   solve_type = 'PJFNK'
 
   petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package -snes_type'
   petsc_options_value = 'lu            superlu_dist          vinewtonrsls'  
 
 #  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_asm_overlap -sub_pc_type -ksp_type -ksp_gmres_restart'
 #  petsc_options_value = ' asm      2              lu            gmres     200'
   l_max_its = 20
   nl_max_its = 10
   nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-8
   nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-9
 
   end_time = 300
 
   [./TimeStepper]
     type = IterationAdaptiveDT
     dt = 5e-3
     cutback_factor = 0.75
     growth_factor = 1.2
     optimal_iterations = 20
   [../]
 
 []

We mean intervals.
So get dt down until you get convergence then see how big the strain increments are

node.title: Chemical potential calcluted with Split formulation Cahn-Hilliard Kernel
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE members,
I am using the Split formulation Cahn-Hilliard Kernel to simulate coupled chemo-mechanical diffusing problems (with kappa=0) with additional eigenstrains, e.g. dislocations.
When I consider the additional eigenstrain, the calculated chemical potential 'w' is quite different from the material properties directly calculated from mu = dF/dc (saved in axuvariable 'mu' through MaterialRealAux), as shown in the following figure.  If there is no additional eigenstrain, the solutions of 'w' and 'mu' are the same.
So what could be the reason for this difference?
Following is my input file:
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  xmin = -25
  xmax = 25
  ymin = -25
  ymax = 25
  nx = 50
  ny = 50
  elem_type = QUAD4
[]

[Variables]
  [./c]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    initial_condition = 0.05
  [../]
  [./w]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]
  [./disp_x]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]
  [./disp_y]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./TensorMechanics]
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  [../]
  [./c_res]
    type = SplitCHParsed
    variable = c
    f_name = F
    kappa_name = kappa_c
    w = w
  [../]
  [./w_res]
    type = SplitCHWRes
    variable = w
    mob_name = M
    coupled_variables = c
  [../]
  [./time]
    type = CoupledTimeDerivative
    variable = w
    v = c
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [./flux]
    type = FunctionNeumannBC
    variable = w
    function = 0.1
    boundary = 'bottom'
  [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./mu]
    order = FIRST
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./d]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./sigma11_aux]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./sigma22_aux]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./sigma12_aux]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
[]
[AuxKernels]
  [./mu]
    type = MaterialRealAux
    property = dF_dc 
    variable = mu
  [../]
  [./d]
    type = FunctionAux
    variable = d
    function = 'if(x>-30&x<0.1&y>-0.6&y<0.6,1,0)'
  [../]
  [./matl_sigma11]
    type = RankTwoAux
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    index_i = 0
    index_j = 0
    variable = sigma11_aux
  [../]
  [./matl_sigma22]
    type = RankTwoAux
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    index_i = 1
    index_j = 1
    variable = sigma22_aux
  [../]
  [./matl_sigma12]
    type = RankTwoAux
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    index_i = 0
    index_j = 1
    variable = sigma11_aux
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./interface]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names  = 'kappa_c'
    prop_values = '0'
  [../]
  [./mobility]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'M'
    coupled_variables = 'c'
    constant_names       = 'D '
    constant_expressions = '1000'
    expression = 'D*c*(1-c)'
    enable_jit = true
    derivative_order = 1
  [../]
  [./chemical_free_energy]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    property_name = Fc
    coupled_variables = 'c'
    constant_names       = 'X '
    constant_expressions = '1'
    expression = 'c*log(c)+(1-c)*log(1-c)+X*c*(1-c)'
    enable_jit = true
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]
  [./elastic_free_energy]
    type = ElasticEnergyMaterial
    f_name = Fe
    args = 'c'
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]
  [./free_energy]
    type = DerivativeSumMaterial
    property_name = F
    sum_materials = 'Fc Fe'
    coupled_variables = 'c'
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]
  [./dFdc]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    property_name = dF_dc
    material_property_names = 'dF:=D[F,c]'
    expression = 'dF'
  [../]
  [./Cijkl_alpha]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 1523.1
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
  [../]
  [./stress]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
  [../]
  [./strain]
    type = ComputeSmallStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    eigenstrain_names = 'eigenstrain_c eigenstrain_D'
  [../]
  [./var_dependence]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    expression = 0.08/3*c
    coupled_variables = c
    f_name = var_dep
    enable_jit = true
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]
  [./eigenstrain]
    type = ComputeVariableEigenstrain
    eigen_base = '1 1 1 0 0 0'
    prefactor = var_dep
    args = 'c'
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain_c
  [../]
  [./var_dis]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    expression = d
    coupled_variables = d
    f_name = var_dis
    enable_jit = true
    derivative_order = 2
  [../]
  [./Dislocation_Eigenstrain]
    type = ComputeVariableEigenstrain
    eigen_base = '0 0 0 0 0 0.2'
    prefactor = var_dis
    args = 'd'
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain_D
  [../]
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  scheme = bdf2

  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type  -sub_pc_type '
  petsc_options_value = 'asm       lu'

  l_max_its = 30
  nl_max_its = 10
  l_tol = 1.0e-4
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-8
  nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-10
  start_time = 0.0
  end_time = 10000

  [./TimeStepper]
    type = SolutionTimeAdaptiveDT
    dt = 1
  [../]
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]
@laagesen @amjokisaari
